text: today on the caucus Megan Liberman and
Jeff Zeleny discussed the possible
presidential campaign of texas governor
rick perry also a longtime texas
reporter looks at the governor's record
in office it is our nature as people
inherently we want to live free and
that's really what this election is all
going to be about so Jeff Rick Perry the
governor of Texas came to New York last
night to speak at the annual Lincoln
dinner or group of Republicans and he
was filling in for Donald Trump and
fueling speculation that he's really
considering getting into this
presidential race he was feeling
speculation he was quite literally
playing the role of Donald Trump he's
known for saying you're fired we're
known for saying you're hired in his
speech he was really doing what he's
done across the country he wasn't giving
too many specifics for a possible
presidential platform the fact is he
hasn't really thought it through that
much if he's going to run or not so it
was a standard stump speech true crowd
pleaser for conservatives but it didn't
offer that much of a window in what he's
really thinking that answer is coming in
private conversations with his team of
strategists and the inner circle
questions got more interesting because
when Newt Gingrich's staff basically had
a mass exodus last week a couple of his
top people were also a long time Rick
Perry people right without a doubt and
one of them was at his side last night
David Carney is a longtime political
strategist he signed up with speaker
Gingrich because at the time it looked
like Governor Perry was not even
thinking about running for president and
he wasn't but now things change he and
others are saying privately you know
this is not a done deal we are looking
at this take him at his word when the
governor says he is looking at this not
not just flirting with it you do already
see the contours of how he would run
that he's positioning himself as a
conservative alternative Mitt Romney and
that one who has sort of he's a governor
though and it's a lot of people trying
to occupy that conservative Tea Party
space but he's governor and someone who
has a story in the economy that he likes
to tell particularly on jobs he does
everywhere he goes he said Texas's
created more jobs of course under his
leadership than any other state combined
you know he doesn't tell the full record
of Texas of course which also has debt
problems and if he decides to run for
and all that will be fully examined but
I think the most important takeaway from
all this is that he is thinking about
running because it seems that there's
still a space in this Republican race
we're almost in the middle of June and
there still is not the perfect candidate
that some conservatives are looking for
he has some things he has to potentially
overcome two statements he's made in the
past he's known for some sort of out
their remarks like suggesting perhaps
that Texas might like to secede things
like that he see me putting a gloss on
that last night talking about sort of
more sober states rights argument and
when you listen to me almost like why do
you want to run for president since the
job would be so diminished under you you
know a rick perry presidency would
basically secede all federal powers back
to the states but i think the point here
is that he is trying to make this big
contrast with you know all the other
establishment republicans in the race
one other thing that he has if he
decides to run is a huge fundraising
rolodex he's the chairman of the
Republican Governors Association which
means that he has contacts all across
the country and if he would decide to
run money would not be a problem for him
but he does have to start actually
raising that money soon and building
infrastructure so he has to make some
kind of decision fairly soon doesn't he
he does without a doubt the iowa straw
poll should he participate and it's
something that you know would probably
do well for him is less than 60 days
away so there's not that much time here
it takes a while to get a presidential
operation underway so he has a couple
weeks to make this decision and you know
at the end of the day we'll see if he is
actually going to go forward or if he's
like all the other governors who have
decided not to run you know that it's
easier to look at it from the outside
but we'll find out
also today je root is a reporter with
The Texas Tribune a non-profit news
organization which partners with the New
York Times to provide coverage he's
covered Rick Perry for almost 15 years
and I've covered Perry since Perry was
he was AG commissioner and then he moved
on to lieutenant governor and then when
bush was elected president then Perry
became governor and I've pretty much
covered Perry ever since he was governor
the last few years is you've heard we
created more jobs than all the other 49
states combined you know the economy in
Texas is clearly better than than most
of the of the rest of the nation but
Texas does have a lot of unemployment
Texas has a lot of poverty but I don't
think there's any dispute that Texas has
weathered the recession better than than
most states you'll hear him say over and
over that you know Texas is fiscally
conservative he'll take credit for
laying the groundwork and creating a
structure that that's what he says over
and over that we in Texas have created
this structure this favorable for
business the federal government was
created by the states to be an agent for
the state not the other way around he
kind of got ahead of the tea party thing
it was in April of 2009 Perry was at a
anti-tax rally we got a great you
but if Washington continues to thumb
their nose at the American people might
come out of that he was roundly
criticized for that but there have also
been commentators who have suggested
that he gained a benefit from it he
walked in with some street cred on you
know as sort of a tea party guy even
though he's been a pretty much in office
most of his adult life
